elements.content: Based on an asymmetric pyridinyl triazole carboxylate ligand 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic acid (Hpmtc), 12 cadmium­(II) polymers {Cd1.5(pmtc)2(NO3)]·H2O} n (1), {[Cd2(pmtc)2(μ2-SO4)­(H2O)]} n (2), [Cd­(pmtc)­(SCN)] n (3), [Cd2(pmtc)2(SCN)2] n (4), {[Cd1.5(pmtc)2(N3)]·H2O} n (5),{[Cd­(pmtc)2]} n (6), [Cd­(pmtc)­(NO2)­(CH3OH)] n (7), {[Cd2(ppmtc)3(NO2)]} n (8), {[Cd2(pmtc)2(Cl)2(H2O)2]} n (9),{[Cd­(pmtc)­(Br)­(H2O)]·CH3OH} n (10), {Cd­(pmtc)­(I)­(H2O)]} n (11), and [Cd­(pmtc)­(I)] n (12) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Employment of different anions has resulted in different architectures and topological structures, ranging from two-dimensional (2D) to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, in which 2 and 4 present a new (42·6·103)­(42·63·8)2(42·6) topology. Through calculations to the frontier molecular orbital (FMOs) of 9–11, their photoluminescence should be assigned as the n → π* transition. Moreover, the photoluminescent properties of 1–12 indicate that the coordination anions make great contribution to fluorescent emission of Cd­(II) polymers.

Employment of different anions has resulted in different architectures and topological structures, ranging from two-dimensional (2D) to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks, in which 2 and 4 present a new (42⋅6⋅103)(42⋅63⋅8)2(42⋅6) topology. Through calculations to the frontier molecular orbital (FMOs) of 9-11, their photoluminescence should be assigned as the n → π* transition. Moreover, the photoluminescent properties of 1-12 indicate that the coordination anions make great contribution to fluorescent emission of Cd(II) polymers.

elements.content: Twelve cadmium­(II) polymers with 2D or 3D structures based on an asymmetric Hpmtc ligand have been synthesized and characterized structurally, in which 2 and 4 show new topology that has not been reported before. The counteranions have significant influence on their structures and photoluminescent properties.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed in recent years and received great attention not only due to their intriguing structures and diverse topologies, but also because of their interesting properties and possible applications as functional materials. However, it is still a big challenge to rationally and predictably prepare the desired crystalline products. The resulting structures will be determined by several factors, including the coordination geometry of metal ions, the structural characteristics of ligands, the solvent system, temperature, counteranions, and so forth. Among these factors, anions have attracted considerable attention due to their great effect on the crystal packing and topologies of coordination polymers in terms of their differences in the size, shape, charge, coordination ability, as well as the coordination modes to metal ions. Anions can coordinate to the metal center in monodentate fashion as well as in a bridging mode, and the bridging ability of the anion has a drastic effect on the dimensionality of the coordination polymers and often leads to varieties of intriguing architectures. Additionally, during the assembly process, anions not only act as the guests and/or counterion to template the construction of host frameworks, but also act as the hydrogen-bonded donor or acceptor to extend the molecular units into high-dimensional networks. Anions, therefore, can be selectively used to increase or reduce the dimensionality of the resulting polymeric network. Although considerable progress has been achieved concerning the role of anions in self-assembly processes, the influence of anions on the self-assembly processes is still less well understood and systematic investigations remain scarce.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed in recent years and received great attention not only due to their intriguing structures and diverse topologies, but also because of their interesting properties and possible applications as functional materials. However, it is still a big challenge to rationally and predictably prepare the desired crystalline products. The resulting structures will be determined by several factors, including the coordination geometry of metal ions, the structural characteristics of ligands, the solvent system, temperature, counteranions, and so forth. Among these factors, anions have attracted considerable attention due to their great effect on the crystal packing and topologies of coordination polymers in terms of their differences in the size, shape, charge, coordination ability, as well as the coordination modes to metal ions. Anions can coordinate to the metal center in monodentate fashion as well as in a bridging mode, and the bridging ability of the anion has a drastic effect on the dimensionality of the coordination polymers and often leads to varieties of intriguing architectures. Additionally, during the assembly process, anions not only act as the guests and/or counterion to template the construction of host frameworks, but also act as the hydrogen-bonded donor or acceptor to extend the molecular units into high-dimensional networks. Anions, therefore, can be selectively used to increase or reduce the dimensionality of the resulting polymeric network. Although considerable progress has been achieved concerning the role of anions in self-assembly processes, the influence of anions on the self-assembly processes is still less well understood and systematic investigations remain scarce.

elements.content: On the other hand, although a large number of organic molecules have been investigated as potential linkers, metal–organic frameworks with diverse topology incorporating carboxylate, pyridine, or triazole ligands have witnessed the most important development. However, the ligands comprising triazole, carboxylate, and pyridine groups have not been studied thoroughly up to now. In this paper, we designed and synthesized a new ligand with one carboxylate, one pyridine and one triazole groups, namely, 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylate (Hpmtc), as a continued investigation concerning the influence of anions on the self-assembly processes, because it has remarkable features in the construction of MOFs: (i) The Hpmtc ligand containing multidentate carboxylate, pyridine, and triazole is a potential multipurpose bridge that could facilitate construction of high-dimensional structures. Additionally, the Hpmtc ligand has one possible steric configuration by rotating pyridine rings with different angles, which therefore can exhibit versatile fashions to satisfy the space geometries of the metal ions. (ii) Weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding and π···π interactions, can be expected in the structural construction. The combination of the Hpmtc ligand and different metal ions can be anticipated in the formation of polymers possessing pleasing architectures, novel topologies, and excellent properties.

In this paper, we designed and synthesized a new ligand with one carboxylate, one pyridine and one triazole groups, namely, 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylate (Hpmtc), as a continued investigation concerning the influence of anions on the self-assembly processes, because it has remarkable features in the construction of MOFs: (i) The Hpmtc ligand containing multidentate carboxylate, pyridine, and triazole is a potential multipurpose bridge that could facilitate construction of high-dimensional structures. Additionally, the Hpmtc ligand has one possible steric configuration by rotating pyridine rings with different angles, which therefore can exhibit versatile fashions to satisfy the space geometries of the metal ions. (ii) Weak interactions, such as hydrogen bonding and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, can be expected in the structural construction. The combination of the Hpmtc ligand and different metal ions can be anticipated in the formation of polymers possessing pleasing architectures, novel topologies, and excellent properties.

elements.content: To further understand the influence of anions, 12 cadmium­(II) coordination frameworks with pmtc– ligand have been synthesized in the presence of different anions [NO3 – (1), SO4 2– (2), SCN– (3, 4), N3 –(5), Ac– (6), NO2 – (7, 8), Cl– (9), Br– (10), I– (11, 12)]. X-ray analyses show that 1–12 possess interesting two-dimensional (2D) or three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with different novel topologies, in which the counteranions display different coordination modes and capabilities, and the nature of the counteranions is the underlying reason for their structural differences. The unusual structures, topologies, roles of anions, and photoluminescence properties are described and discussed in detail. To the best of our knowledge, this paper presents the largest number of inorganic anions that have been involved in coordination in all the reported literature, which offers an opportunity for us to discuss the roles of anions.

elements.content: All materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Infrared spectra data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm–1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric measurements (TGA, 30–800 °C) were recorded on a Netzsch STA409PC differential thermal analyzer using air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was measured on PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD system. 1H NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker AVIII HD 400 MHz spectrometer. The luminescent measurements for the solid samples were performed at room temperature using a HITACHI F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The excitation slit and the emission slit were 5 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information and Materials

All materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Infrared spectra data were recorded on a BRUKER TENSOR 27 spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a FLASH EA 1112 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric measurements (TGA, 30-800 °C) were recorded on a Netzsch STA409PC differential thermal analyzer using air atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was measured on PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD system. 1H NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker AVIII HD 400 MHz spectrometer. The luminescent measurements for the solid samples were performed at room temperature using a HITACHI F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The excitation slit and the emission slit were 5 nm.

elements.content:
The lithium 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole- 3-carboxylate ligand was synthesized according to the procedure described in .

Synthesis of 1-(4-Pyridinylmethyl)-1<italic>H</italic>-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic Methyl Ester

1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic methyl ester (4.30 g, 0.034 mol), 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride (5 g, 0.04 mol), and K2CO3 (10.12 g, 0.073 mol) were dissolved in 80 mL of acetonitrile solution. The mixture was stirred and heated to reflux for 24 h. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the brick-red solid was chromatographed on silica gel with CH3CH2OH/CH2Cl2 (1:28); the white solid was obtained (4.85 g, 0.022 mol) in 65% yield.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Ligand

The lithium 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole- 3-carboxylate ligand was synthesized according to the procedure described in .

Synthesis of 1-(4-Pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic Methyl Ester

1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic methyl ester (4.30 g, 0.034 mol), 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride (5 g, 0.04 mol), and K2CO3 (10.12 g, 0.073 mol) were dissolved in 80 mL of acetonitrile solution. The mixture was stirred and heated to reflux for 24 h. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the brick-red solid was chromatographed on silica gel with CH3CH2OH/CH2Cl2 (1:28); the white solid was obtained (4.85 g, 0.022 mol) in 65% yield.

elements.content: All the DFT calculations were performed by using the Gaussian 09 suite of programs. The frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) of all concerned complexes were predicted by single-point energy calculations to the X-ray crystal structures, with the B3LYP functional and the mixed basis sets (LanL2DZ for Cd­(II), and 6-31g­(d,p) for the rest) adopted.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

All the DFT calculations were performed by using the Gaussian 09 suite of programs. The frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) of all concerned complexes were predicted by single-point energy calculations to the X-ray crystal structures, with the B3LYP functional and the mixed basis sets (LanL2DZ for Cd(II), and 6-31g(d,p) for the rest) adopted.

Polymer 7 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and NaNO2 (3.5 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:3, 6 mL) at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature, bright yellow of 7 were collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C10H11CdN5O5 (%): C, 30.48; H, 2.79; N, 17.78. Found: C, 30.59; H, 2.86; N, 17.67. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3128m, 2107m, 1611s, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1236s, 1270s, 1027m, 825m, 666w, 587w (Figure S2).

elements.content: The data of 2–12 were collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα ray, λ = 0.71073 Å) at temperature of 298 ± 1 K, while the data of 1 were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα ray, λ = 0.71073 Å). All structures were solved with direct methods with the SHELXS-97 crystallographic software package and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique with the SHELXL-2014 programs, respectively. The data of 2, 6, 8, 9, and 11 were corrected with SQUEEZE to remove the solvent molecules due to severe crystallographic disorder. The processing parameters and crystallographic data for 1–12 are presented in , , and . shows the summary information on 1–12 including Schläfli symbol, topological type, dimensionality, etc.

Crystal Data Collection and Refinement

The data of 2-12 were collected on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα ray, λ = 0.71073 Å) at temperature of 298 ± 1 K, while the data of 1 were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα ray, λ = 0.71073 Å). All structures were solved with direct methods with the SHELXS-97 crystallographic software package and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique with the SHELXL-2014 programs, respectively. The data of 2, 6, 8, 9, and 11 were corrected with SQUEEZE to remove the solvent molecules due to severe crystallographic disorder. The processing parameters and crystallographic data for 1-12 are presented in , , and .  shows the summary information on 1-12 including Schläfli symbol, topological type, dimensionality, etc.

Coordination modes of the pmtc– ligand are shown in Scheme (a-i).

The single-crystal structure analysis of 1 indicates a 3D framework which crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅ (). There are two types of crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ions (Cd1 and Cd2 have 1/2 and 1 site occupancy, respectively), two pmtc– ligands, one NO3 – anion, and one lattice water in an asymmetric unit. The pmtc– ligand possesses two types of coordination modes: μ3-kN:kN′,O:kO, and μ3-kN:kN′,O:kO′ (a and c). As depicted in a, the Cd1 center displays a slightly distorted octahedral environment defined by two nitrogen atoms (N6, N6D) and two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1D) from two chelating pmtc– ligands, and two oxygen atoms (O6, O6D) from two NO3 – anions. The Cd2 ion is also in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry comprising O3, N5 from one chelating pmtc– ligand, two carboxyl oxygen (O2, O3A), and two pyridine nitrogen (N1C, N2B) atoms from other four pmtc– ligands. The Cd–N bond lengths vary from 2.295(3) to 2.370(3) Å, while the Cd–O bond lengths are from 2.278(3) to 2.458(3) Å, which are in the normal range (Table S1).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {Cd1.5(pmtc)2(NO3)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

The single-crystal structure analysis of 1 indicates a 3D framework which crystallizes in the triclinic system with space group P1̅ (). There are two types of crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions (Cd1 and Cd2 have 1/2 and 1 site occupancy, respectively), two pmtc- ligands, one NO3 - anion, and one lattice water in an asymmetric unit. The pmtc- ligand possesses two types of coordination modes: μ3-kN:kN',O:kO, and μ3-kN:kN',O:kO' (a and c). As depicted in a, the Cd1 center displays a slightly distorted octahedral environment defined by two nitrogen atoms (N6, N6D) and two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1D) from two chelating pmtc- ligands, and two oxygen atoms (O6, O6D) from two NO3 - anions. The Cd2 ion is also in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry comprising O3, N5 from one chelating pmtc- ligand, two carboxyl oxygen (O2, O3A), and two pyridine nitrogen (N1C, N2B) atoms from other four pmtc- ligands. The Cd-N bond lengths vary from 2.295(3) to 2.370(3) Å, while the Cd-O bond lengths are from 2.278(3) to 2.458(3) Å, which are in the normal range (Table S1).

Color scheme: carbon = gray, nitrogen = blue, oxygen = red, metal = sky blue.

In this structure, the adjacent Cd1 ions are bridged by two μ2-η2:η0 bridging carboxylate groups to provide a binuclear {Cd2O2} unit with the nonbonding Cd···Cd distance of 3.891(2) Å; then binuclear {Cd2O2} units are connected together by carboxylate groups with an interval of one Cd1 ion and form a 1D liner chain (b). It is interesting to note that NO3 – acting as the terminal ligands participates in coordination. The adjacent chains are held together to give a novel 3D network structure through the connectivity of the pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligands (d). To gain further insight into the structure of 1, it is necessary to simplify the Cd­(II) from the topological of view. Binuclear Cd2 and Cd1 can be simplified as eight-connected node and four-connected node, respectively, while the pmtc– ligands are ignored. Therefore, the whole structure can be represented as a 2-nodal (4,8)-connected sqc21 topological network with the point symbol (32·42·52)­(34·48·512·64) (c and ).

elements.content: Polymer 2 crystallizes in monoclinic system with space group P21/c and shows 3D supramolecular frameworks, too. The asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically distinguishing Cd­(II) ions, two pmtc– ligands, one SO4 2– anion, and one coordinated water molecule. As shown in a, the Cd1 is located in a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry, in which the equatorial plane is defined by four N,O chelating coordinate atoms (O1, N4, O3, N8) from two individual pmtc– ligands and one oxygen atom (O11B) from SO4 2– anion, one pyridine nitrogen atom (N5A), and one oxygen atom (O11) from another SO4 2– anion occupying the axial positions. Each Cd2 is located in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, in which the equatorial plane is defined by three oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O4C), one nitrogen atom (N6C), and the axial sites are occupied by pyridine nitrogen atom (N1D) and oxygen atom (O5) coming from terminal coordination water. The Cd–N [2.295(3)–2.370(3) Å] and Cd–O [2.278(3)–2.458(3) Å] bond distances (Table S1) are comparable to the values found in the previously published reports.

Crystal Structure of {[Cd2(pmtc)2(μ 2-SO4)(H2O)]} n  (2)

Polymer 2 crystallizes in monoclinic system with space group P21/c and shows 3D supramolecular frameworks, too. The asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically distinguishing Cd(II) ions, two pmtc- ligands, one SO4 2- anion, and one coordinated water molecule. As shown in a, the Cd1 is located in a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry, in which the equatorial plane is defined by four N,O chelating coordinate atoms (O1, N4, O3, N8) from two individual pmtc- ligands and one oxygen atom (O11B) from SO4 2- anion, one pyridine nitrogen atom (N5A), and one oxygen atom (O11) from another SO4 2- anion occupying the axial positions. Each Cd2 is located in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, in which the equatorial plane is defined by three oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O4C), one nitrogen atom (N6C), and the axial sites are occupied by pyridine nitrogen atom (N1D) and oxygen atom (O5) coming from terminal coordination water. The Cd-N [2.295(3)-2.370(3) Å] and Cd-O [2.278(3)-2.458(3) Å] bond distances (Table S1) are comparable to the values found in the previously published reports.

elements.content: The pmtc– ligand adopts two types of coordination modes, namely, μ3-kN:kN′,O:kO, and μ4-kN:kN′,O:kN″,O′:kO′ (a and d), respectively. In 2, Cd1 and Cd2 are bridged by bridging carboxylate groups to form a Cd2O2 ring with Cd1···Cd2 of 3.9908(5) Å. The chelate pmtc– ligand behave as a bidentate ligand to link neighboring Cd2O2 ring to form 1D zigzag chain. Since the −CH2– can bend and rotate freely, adjacent 1D chains are connected by pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligands to form the double layer. It is interesting to note that the double-bridged SO4 2– plays the key role in the formation of the framework. The sulfate acting as μ2-connector further links neighboring double layers to form the resultant 3D metal–organic framework. In the 3D framework, there exists a Cd4(SO4)2 unit, with Cd···Cd distance of 4.5553(4) Å (b). For better understanding of this 3D motif, 2 can be clearly simplified through topological considerations, as illustrated in c. Each sulfate anions is simplified by a linear linker, Cd1 atoms can be abstracted as a three-connected node which links to three pmtc– ligands, and Cd2 atoms can be abstracted as a four-connected node which links to four pmtc– ligands. Two kinds of pmtc– ligands can be simplified as three-connected node and four-connected node, respectively. The overall structure of 2 is a 3D net with (42·6·103)­(42·63·8)2(42·6) topology (c and ), which is a new framework topology and has not been reported before.

elements.content: The pmtc– ligands act as tridentate ligands to link three metal atoms through one pyridine nitrogen atom and two carboxyl oxygen atoms (namely, μ3-kN:kN′,O:kO′) (c). As shown in b, the neighboring Cd­(II) ions are bridged by μ2-SCN– ligands to form an eight atoms {Cd­(SCN)2Cd} circuit unit with a Cd···Cd distance of 5.8174(3) Å. In addition, two pmtc– ligands bridge two Cd­(II) ions to form a {Cd2L2} ring with a Cd···Cd distance of 9.9198(4) Å. Neighboring {Cd2L2} loops are integrated together by μ2-bridging SCN– ions to form an infinite 1D chain containing alternating {Cd2L2} loops and {Cd­(SCN)2Cd} circuit units (b). Further, these 1D loop chains are cross-linked carboxyl oxygen atoms as a bridging linker to give birth to a 3D framework (c). To better understand the complicated 3D structure of 3, topological analysis is carried out. Topologically, the pmtc– ligand links three Cd­(II) and the dinuclear Cd­(II) ions links six pmtc– ligands in turn, while SCN– acting as two-connected nodes are ignored. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 3 is a 3,6-connected alb-3,6-P42/mnm topological net with its point (Schlafli) symbol of (4·82)2(42·811·102) (c and ).

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 5 belongs to the triclinic system with space group P1̅, and the asymmetric unit contains two pmtc– ligands, one and a half Cd­(II) ions, one terminal coordinated N3 – anion, and one free water molecule (a). The Cd1 ion is in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry defined by O1, N7, O1B, N7B atoms from two N,O chelating pmtc– ligands, and two nitrogen atoms (N2, N2B) from two N3 – anions. In contrast, Cd2 ion is hept-coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4A, O4C) and three nitrogen (N8C, N9, N10A) from five pmtc– ligands, in which the equatorial plane comprises five atoms (O1, O2, O4A, O4C, N10A), and two pyridine nitrogen atoms (N8C, N9) occupy the apical sites with the N8C–Cd2–N9 angle of 171.9°. The general Cd–O and Cd–N bond separations are in the range of 2.275(2)–2.470(2) Å and 2.258(4)–2.369(3) Å, respectively (Table S1), falling in the rational bond lengths.

elements.content: In 5, the pmtc– ligand exhibits two different coordination modes (a and c). Similar with 1, the adjacent Cd2 ions are bridged by two μ2-η2:η0 bridging carboxylate groups to provide a binuclear {Cd2O2} unit with the Cd···Cd distance of 3.9302(3) Å, which is longer than that of 1, then the binuclear {Cd2O2} units are further connected together by carboxylate groups with an interval of Cd1, which form a 1D liner chain (b). The 1D linker chain of 5 is almost identical to that of 1. Unlike the case of 1, N3 – instead of NO3 – acts as the terminal ligands participate in coordination, and the adjacent chains are held together to give a novel 3D network through the connection of the terminal pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligands which coordinated with Cd2 in the axial positions. To get a better insight into the present 3D framework structure, topological analysis was carried out for 5; each Cd1 was connected by two pmtc– ligands which can be considered as a line. Similarly, each Cd2 was linked by five pmtc– ligands; it can be viewed as a 5-connected node. On the other hand, each pmtc– ligand in 5-connected three Cd­(II) ions; they can thus be treated as 3-connected nodes, respectively. The resulting structure of 5 can be simplified to a 3,5-connected ZIHTEP framework with the Schläfli symbol of (42·62·86)­(42·6)­(62·8) (c and ).

elements.content: There are two different types of pmtc– ligands, which adopt two coordination modes μ3-kN: kN′,O:kO and μ2-kN:kO,O′ (a and b). In 6, the pmtc– ligand behaves as a bidentate ligand to yield a binuclear metallocycle {Cd2O2} with the Cd···Cd separation of 4.0839(3) Å. The binuclear metallocycles are connected by pmtc– ligands to form closed rings with the diagonal Cd···Cd distances being 9.7679(4) × 13.9780(6) Å, which results in a 1D chain. Then the neighboring chains are linked by chelating carboxyl groups and pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligands to yield a 2D double sheet, in which the pmtc– ligands connect the previously mentioned binuclear metallocycles to form another closed rings with the diagonal Cd···Cd distances being 9.5732(4) × 13.5132(7) Å (c). In 6, there is no interpenetration between neighboring layers, generating large cavities with the potential for inclusion of water and methanol molecules. Furthermore, between two pyridine rings of two adjacent layers, there are π···π interactions with average center-to-center separation 3.848 Å, which result in a 3D structure. After the removal of the free ethanol molecules, 6 is microporous and has a total potential solvent accessible volume of 18.8%, as calculated using PLATON (). From a topological viewpoint, the binuclear Cd­(II) can be considered as a four-connected node, while two kinds of pmtc– ligands with different coordinated mode which can be considered as a line, are ignored. On the basis of the simplification above, 6 possesses a sql net with the Schläfli symbol of (44·62) (c and ).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 7 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with a C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of 7 consists of one Cd­(II) ion, one pmtc– ligand, one NO2 – anion, and one methanol molecule. As shown in a, the Cd­(II) ion is eight-coordinated and in a slight distorted capped pentagonal bipyramid coordination environment by two carboxylate oxygen (O4B, O5B) from one pmtc– ligand, two N,O chelating coordinate atoms (N5A, O5A) from the other pmtc– ligand, two oxygen atoms from one NO2 – (O2, O3) anion, one pyridine nitrogen atom (N2) from another pmtc– ligand, and one oxygen atom (O1) from one methanol molecular, which is quite rare among the Cd­(II) complexes. The carboxyl oxygen atoms of pmtc– ligands adopt μ2-η1:η2 bridging mode to connect two adjacent Cd­(II) ions resulting in the 1D chains. Simultaneously, the pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligands further link Cd­(II) ions of the neighboring chains resulting in the 2D layer framework (b). Furthermore, between two adjacent interlayer triazole rings of pmtc– ligands, there are π···π interactions with average center-to-center separation 3.686 Å, which result in the 3D structure. From the topological point of view, if the Cd­(II) are regarded as three-connected nodes, and the pmtc– ligands are viewed as three-connected nodes, the overall structure of 7 is a 2D (3,3)-connected fes network with (4·82)­(4·82) topology (c and ).

Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 7 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with a C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of 7 consists of one Cd(II) ion, one pmtc- ligand, one NO2 - anion, and one methanol molecule. As shown in a, the Cd(II) ion is eight-coordinated and in a slight distorted capped pentagonal bipyramid coordination environment by two carboxylate oxygen (O4B, O5B) from one pmtc- ligand, two N,O chelating coordinate atoms (N5A, O5A) from the other pmtc- ligand, two oxygen atoms from one NO2 - (O2, O3) anion, one pyridine nitrogen atom (N2) from another pmtc- ligand, and one oxygen atom (O1) from one methanol molecular, which is quite rare among the Cd(II) complexes. The carboxyl oxygen atoms of pmtc- ligands adopt μ2-η1:η2 bridging mode to connect two adjacent Cd(II) ions resulting in the 1D chains. Simultaneously, the pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc- ligands further link Cd(II) ions of the neighboring chains resulting in the 2D layer framework (b). Furthermore, between two adjacent interlayer triazole rings of pmtc- ligands, there are π⋅⋅⋅π interactions with average center-to-center separation 3.686 Å, which result in the 3D structure. From the topological point of view, if the Cd(II) are regarded as three-connected nodes, and the pmtc- ligands are viewed as three-connected nodes, the overall structure of 7 is a 2D (3,3)-connected fes network with (4⋅82)(4⋅82) topology (c and ).

The asymmetric unit of 8 contains two crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ions, three pmtc– ligands, one NO2 – anion, one methanol, and two free water molecules. The two Cd­(II) ions exist in two different coordination environments. Cd1 is six-coordinated and in a distorted octahedral environment by two oxygens (O2, O2B), three nitrogen donors (N1C, N4B, N5) from four different pmtc– ligands, and one H2O molecule (O3A), while Cd2 is seven-coordinated and in a distorted pentagonal bipyramid by five atoms (O4, N8, O7, N10, N13) from three pmtc– ligands, two oxygen atoms (O5, O6) from one NO2 – anion in which two oxygen atoms O4 and O7 occupy the apical sites with the O4–Cd2–O7 angle of 174.1°, and the remaining atoms forming the equatorial plane.

elements.content: In 8, two different types of pmtc– ligands adopt three coordination modes (e, g, and i). The carboxyl groups of pmtc– ligand take μ2-η2:η0 mode to connect two Cd1 forming {Cd2O2} ring with the Cd···Cd distance is 3.9347(4) Å. Carboxyl group with μ2-η1:η1 coordination mode of pmtc– ligands link {Cd2O2} rings and Cd2 forming a 1D chain. The 1D chains are further connected through terminal pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligands to form a 3D structure (b). Furthermore, two pmtc– ligands bridge two Cd2 ions to form a {Cd2L2} cyclic structure with the Cd···Cd distance of 9.8562(4) Å. The solvent-accessible volume, calculated with the PLATON program, is 14.4% of the total unit cell volume (). Topologically, if the pmtc– ligands are considered as three nodes, and Cd­(II) ion can be defined as five-connected nodes, the structure of 8 can be described as a (3,5)-connected ZIHTEP topological network with the point symbol (42·62·86)­(42·6)­(62·8) (c and ).

As shown in a, the asymmetric unit of 9 has two crystallographically unique Cd­(II) ions, two pmtc– ligands, two Cl– anions, and two coordinated H2O molecules. Both Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are in a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry, in which the equatorial plane is defined by two N,O chelating coordinate atoms (O5B, N8B for Cd1 and O2, N3 for Cd2), two chelating carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, O2 for Cd1 and O5A, O6A for Cd2) of pmtc– ligands, and one oxygen atom from terminal coordination water (O4 for Cd1, O3 for Cd2). elements.content: Interestingly, each pmtc– adopts μ3-kN:kN′,O:kO′,O″ coordination mode (f) linking Cd­(II) ions to give rise to an extended 2D layer (b). Two crystallographically equal Cd­(II) centers are bridged by carboxylate oxygen atoms of pmtc– ligands to form a 1D infinite inorganic chain [−O–Cd–O−] with the neighboring intrachain Cd···Cd distance 4.9171(5) and 4.8981(5) Å, respectively. The Cl– anions act as the monodentate ligands and decorate the side of the 1D inorganic chains. Moreover, the adjacent 1D chains are bridged by pmtc– ligands into a 2D sheet with intralayer channels (b). It is worth noting that, in the 2D double layer, there exits {Cd2L2} rings with Cd···Cd distance of 9.7753(7) Å. The 1D intralayer channels with the approximate channel diameter 5.0 Å exist along the b axis, and the solvent water molecules reside in the channels. The adjacent 2D layers were further connected to form a 3D supramolecular architecture via some weak interactions. After the removal of the free water molecules of 9, it became microporous, with a total potential solvent accessible volume of 19.6% calculated using PLATON (). From the topological point of view, each Cd1 (or Cd2) center, being connected by three pmtc– ligands, can be simplified as a three connected node. Both kinds of pmtc– ligands can be simplified as a three connected node. Accordingly, the whole network can be described as a 2D 3,3-connected fes topology with the Schläfli symbol (4·82)­(4·82) (c and ).

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 10 and 11 have similar structures and exhibit an infinite 2D network. Herein, we only describe the structure of 10 in detail. Polymer 10 crystallized in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. As shown in a, the asymmetric unit of 10 consists of one crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ion, one pmtc– ligand, one coordinated water molecule, one Br– anion, and one methanol solvent molecule. The central Cd­(II) ion is seven-coordinated and in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry, in which the equatorial plane is defined by two N,O chelating coordinate atoms of pmtc– ligand (O3A, N2A), two chelating carboxyl oxygen atoms (O2B, O3B), and one oxygen atom from terminal water molecules. The apical sites are occupied by one nitrogen atom (N1) from one pmtc– ligand and one Br– anion with the Br1–Cd1–N1 (I1–Cd1–N1) angle of 173.6° (173.5°). The Cd–N bond lengths vary from 2.3768 to 2.4316 Å, the Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.3515–2.6119 Å, and Cd–Br (Cd–I) bond length is equal to 2.645 Å (2.802 Å) (Table S1), which are in good accordance with the reported Cd­(II) complexes. It should be noted that the pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is rare in Cd­(II) complexes.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 12 crystallized in the orthorhombic system with Pna21 space group. The asymmetrical unit of 12 contains one crystallographically unique Cd­(II) ion, one pmtc– ligand, and one I– anion. As shown in a, the Cd­(II) center is six-coordinated, exhibiting a CdN3O2I environment composed of three nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from three independent pmtc– ligands, and one I– ion. There is only one type of pmtc– ligand in 12, which adopts the coordination modes μ3-kN: kN′,O:kN″,O′ (h). Each pmtc– ligand connects two Cd­(II) through two N,O chelating atoms of pmtc– ligand to form a 1D chain with the adjacent Cd···Cd distance of 6.0692(5) Å (b). The infinite 1D chains are further interconnected by pyridine nitrogen atoms of pmtc– ligand resulting in a 3D metal–organic framework (d). A similar topological approach was used to analyze the intricate structure of 12. According to the depiction above, each Cd­(II) ion was connected by three pmtc– ligands; hence, it can be considered as a 3-connected node. On the other hand, each pmtc– ligand in 12 connected three Cd­(II) atoms, and thus be treated as a 3-connected node. The whole framework of 12 is accordingly simplified as illustrated in d and , which is also (3,3)-connected utp-d topology with the Schläfli symbol (103·103).

elements.content: In this work, it is interesting that almost all of these polymers are constructed by the combination of Cd­(II), pmtc– ligands, and inorganic ions except for Ac–. As shown in , the anions Ac– do not coordinate with Cd­(II) ion and serve as the structural-directing agents to result in the formation of 2D structure of 6. In 1 and 5, the NO3 – and N3 – anions act as the terminal ligand to bind to Cd­(II) ions, which leads to the formation of 3D framework, while in 2 and 3, different from NO3 – and N3 –, the SO4 2– and SCN– anions act as the bridging ligands with a slightly big steric hindrance to bind to two adjacent Cd­(II) ions and further link the 2D structure to the 3D framework. Furthermore, the SCN– anion is a versatile ligand with two donor atoms, which gives rise to linkage isomers or polymers and forms a variety of different coordination modes in coordination polymers. A striking structural feature is that two kinds of coordinated fashions of SCN– are found in 4, terminal SCN– and bridging SCN–, while they serve only as bridging modes in 3. The SCN– anions in 3 and 4 adopt bridging modes to result in the 3D structure. It is well-known that the introduction of a linker adopting the chelating coordination mode is capable of “passivating” metal sites and may induce lower-dimensional complexes. In 7 and 8, the counteranion NO2 – adopts a chelating mode, which makes 7 and 8 extend in two directions and result in the similar 2D sheet structure. Furthermore, in 8, because of the solvent effect, the 2D sheet structure is further linked by pmtc– ligands to result in the 3D framework. In 9–11, the halogen ions (Cl–, Br–, I–) act as terminal ligands with the corresponding small steric hindrance to bind to Cd­(II) ions, which results in 2D structures, indicating that they have no significant difference in 2D structures. Compared with Cl– and Br– ions, I– ion as the terminal ligand has a slightly larger steric hindrance which results in the 3D structure of 12.
elements.clean_text:
Roles of Anions

In this work, it is interesting that almost all of these polymers are constructed by the combination of Cd(II), pmtc- ligands, and inorganic ions except for Ac-. As shown in , the anions Ac- do not coordinate with Cd(II) ion and serve as the structural-directing agents to result in the formation of 2D structure of 6. In 1 and 5, the NO3 - and N3 - anions act as the terminal ligand to bind to Cd(II) ions, which leads to the formation of 3D framework, while in 2 and 3, different from NO3 - and N3 -, the SO4 2- and SCN- anions act as the bridging ligands with a slightly big steric hindrance to bind to two adjacent Cd(II) ions and further link the 2D structure to the 3D framework. Furthermore, the SCN- anion is a versatile ligand with two donor atoms, which gives rise to linkage isomers or polymers and forms a variety of different coordination modes in coordination polymers. A striking structural feature is that two kinds of coordinated fashions of SCN- are found in 4, terminal SCN- and bridging SCN-, while they serve only as bridging modes in 3. The SCN- anions in 3 and 4 adopt bridging modes to result in the 3D structure. It is well-known that the introduction of a linker adopting the chelating coordination mode is capable of "passivating" metal sites and may induce lower-dimensional complexes. In 7 and 8, the counteranion NO2 - adopts a chelating mode, which makes 7 and 8 extend in two directions and result in the similar 2D sheet structure. Furthermore, in 8, because of the solvent effect, the 2D sheet structure is further linked by pmtc- ligands to result in the 3D framework. In 9-11, the halogen ions (Cl-, Br-, I-) act as terminal ligands with the corresponding small steric hindrance to bind to Cd(II) ions, which results in 2D structures, indicating that they have no significant difference in 2D structures. Compared with Cl- and Br- ions, I- ion as the terminal ligand has a slightly larger steric hindrance which results in the 3D structure of 12.

elements.clean_text: 3  Syntheses of 1-12

elements.content: On the other hand, we have to mention that the nature (coordinating ability, size, and geometry) of Cd­(II) is flexible in different coordination geometries, which makes it capable of forming complexes with five-, six-, seven-, or eight-coordination numbers, resulting in the high-dimensional frameworks. When NO3 – is used as the counteranion, Cd­(II) exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry in 1. With the introduction of SO4 2– , N3 –, NO2 –, and SCN– in 2–5, Cd­(II) adopts distorted pentagonal bipyramidal or distorted octahedral coordination geometries. It is interesting that the introduction of NO2 – in 7 and 8 can cause the rare slightly distorted capped pentagonal pyramid coordination environment of Cd­(II). However, the use of Cl–, Br–, and I– in 9–11 results in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometries of Cd­(II). Furthermore, I– ions also can result in only distorted octahedral geometry in 12. The difference in the coordination environment of the central Cd­(II) ions may depend on the size and coordination mode of the counteranions.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, we have to mention that the nature (coordinating ability, size, and geometry) of Cd(II) is flexible in different coordination geometries, which makes it capable of forming complexes with five-, six-, seven-, or eight-coordination numbers, resulting in the high-dimensional frameworks. When NO3 - is used as the counteranion, Cd(II) exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry in 1. With the introduction of SO4 2- , N3 -, NO2 -, and SCN- in 2-5, Cd(II) adopts distorted pentagonal bipyramidal or distorted octahedral coordination geometries. It is interesting that the introduction of NO2 - in 7 and 8 can cause the rare slightly distorted capped pentagonal pyramid coordination environment of Cd(II). However, the use of Cl-, Br-, and I- in 9-11 results in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometries of Cd(II). Furthermore, I- ions also can result in only distorted octahedral geometry in 12. The difference in the coordination environment of the central Cd(II) ions may depend on the size and coordination mode of the counteranions.

elements.content: Generally, the nature of the anions (namely, the volume, shape, and charge), especially their coordination modes, are the underlying reason behind the differences in the structures of 1–12. The coordination environment of the Cd­(II) center and the coordination modes of the pmtc– ligand are surely dependent on the size and coordination tendency of the counteranions, which lead to polymers with diverse dimension and complexity. The result is consistent with the previous conclusion that counteranions with different coordination modes or abilities can play a key role in crystal engineering, which suggests that selection of appropriate anions would be an ideal way to construct novel coordination polymers.

elements.content: In order to investigate the thermal stabilities of 1–6, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been performed, as shown in Figure S3. The complexes were heated in a temperature range of 30–800 °C in air atmosphere. It can be found that the TG curves of 1, 2, 5, and 6 show three-step weight loss, while 3 and 4 exhibit two-step weight loss. For 1, 2 and 5, 6, the first step of decomposition can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules, coordinated water molecules, or solvent molecules. The second and third sharp weight loss is corresponding to the collapse of the framework. The TG curves of 3 and 4 reveal that the frameworks of 3 and 4 are thermally stable up to 310 °C. Complex 3 begins to decompose at 310 °C and ends at about 683 °C. 4 undergoes sharp destruction ranging from 310 to 660 °C. In the end, all the complexes form CdO as the product at 672 °C for 1, 708 °C for 2, 683 °C for 3, 660 °C for 4, 610 °C for 5, and 644 °C for 6. Table S2 reports the calculated and experimental weight losses, and the temperature range of decomposition for 1–6.

elements.content: Recently, polymeric Cd­(II) complexes with d configuration have been intensively investigated for attractive fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. In the present work, the luminescent properties of 1–6 and 9–11, together with the ligand pmtcLi, were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The bulk purity of 1–6 and 9–11 was substantiated through comparing the PXRD of experimental result to a simulated one of single crystal structure (Figure S4). As shown in a, the free ligand shows intense luminescence with emission maxima at 415 nm (λex = 340 nm) which is assigned to the π–π* transitions. For 1–6 and 9–11, the emission peaks are 409 nm (λex = 350 nm), 405 nm (λex = 340 nm), 393 nm (λex = 326 nm), 415 nm (λex = 344 nm), 426 nm (λex = 365 nm), 403 nm (λex = 336 nm), 409 nm (λex = 346 nm), 372 nm (λex = 314 nm), 386 nm (λex = 340 nm), respectively. Compared to the pmtcLi ligand, the emission bands of 1–4, 6, and 9–11 are 6, 10, 22, 0, 12, 6, 43, and 29 nm blue-shifted, respectively, while the emission bands of 5 are 11 nm red-shifted. The luminescence of 1–6 and 9–11 should be assigned to the intraligand π → π* and/or n → π* transitions, whereas the less than 50 nm wavelength shifts are probably caused by the coordination effect. For 1, 5, 6, and 9, the effective enhancement of emission bands should be due to the formation of various noncovalent interactions, which effectively increases the rigidity of organics and reduces the nonradiative decay of the intraligand excited state. However, SCN– or SO4 2– in 2, 3, and 4 have a negative effect on the fluorescence intensity, which results in the significant weaken of emission bands. Furthermore, there are stacking interactions in 3/4 with the center-to-center separations of 3.456/3.773 Å, respectively, which has also the negative effect on the fluorescence intensity. Additionally, the disorders of pmtc– ligands of 2 and SCN– ions of 4 in crystallography have the negative effect on their fluorescence intensity. Different delocalization environments may be also an important factor on influencing different luminescent behaviors (red-shift or blue-shift) of 1–6 and 9–11.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Analysis

Recently, polymeric Cd(II) complexes with d configuration have been intensively investigated for attractive fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. In the present work, the luminescent properties of 1-6 and 9-11, together with the ligand pmtcLi, were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The bulk purity of 1-6 and 9-11 was substantiated through comparing the PXRD of experimental result to a simulated one of single crystal structure (Figure S4). As shown in a, the free ligand shows intense luminescence with emission maxima at 415 nm (λex = 340 nm) which is assigned to the π-π* transitions. For 1-6 and 9-11, the emission peaks are 409 nm (λex = 350 nm), 405 nm (λex = 340 nm), 393 nm (λex = 326 nm), 415 nm (λex = 344 nm), 426 nm (λex = 365 nm), 403 nm (λex = 336 nm), 409 nm (λex = 346 nm), 372 nm (λex = 314 nm), 386 nm (λex = 340 nm), respectively. Compared to the pmtcLi ligand, the emission bands of 1-4, 6, and 9-11 are 6, 10, 22, 0, 12, 6, 43, and 29 nm blue-shifted, respectively, while the emission bands of 5 are 11 nm red-shifted. The luminescence of 1-6 and 9-11 should be assigned to the intraligand π → π* and/or n → π* transitions, whereas the less than 50 nm wavelength shifts are probably caused by the coordination effect. For 1, 5, 6, and 9, the effective enhancement of emission bands should be due to the formation of various noncovalent interactions, which effectively increases the rigidity of organics and reduces the nonradiative decay of the intraligand excited state. However, SCN- or SO4 2- in 2, 3, and 4 have a negative effect on the fluorescence intensity, which results in the significant weaken of emission bands. Furthermore, there are stacking interactions in 3/4 with the center-to-center separations of 3.456/3.773 Å, respectively, which has also the negative effect on the fluorescence intensity. Additionally, the disorders of pmtc- ligands of 2 and SCN- ions of 4 in crystallography have the negative effect on their fluorescence intensity. Different delocalization environments may be also an important factor on influencing different luminescent behaviors (red-shift or blue-shift) of 1-6 and 9-11.

elements.content: Notably, polymers 9–11 have similar structures; however, the fluorescence intensity of 10 (b) is largely stronger than those of 9, 11, free ligand, and other polymers, and the emission peak has a large blue shift. From a viewpoint of coordination chemistry, they are very suitable for the research of luminescence properties. For Cd­(II) coordination complexes in general, the nature of the metal center and ligands, as well as the rigid structure, are the outcome of the interplay of factors governing luminescent origin of the lowest-lying emissive states. To investigate the luminescent origin of the lowest-lying emissive states, we conducted theoretical calculates to the frontier molecular orbitals of 9–11 by using the density functional theory (DFT) method. As shown in , S5, and S6 (Supporting Information), the contour plots of the relevant HOMO–1, HOMO, LUMO, and LUMO+1 for 9–11, together with the orbital energies and the main atomic orbital contributions, show high similarity. For 9–11, their HOMOs and LUMO orbitals are mainly associated with the n character from the O (COO–) and X (X = Cl, Br, or I), and the energy gap between these two FMOs are very small. However, their LUMO+1 orbitals are mainly associated with the π*-antibonding orbital from the pmtc– ligand. Relative to the other orbitals, their LUMO+1 orbital have the higher orbital energies. According to analyses to energy barriers of various orbitals, we found that the transition of HOMO → LUMO+1 should be the dominant transition, leading to the possible n → π* transition. The result is consistent with the conclusion above and previously reported literature. Furthermore, compared with the emission intensity of 9 (HOMO–LUMO+1 energy gap: 4.16 eV), 10 exhibits the largely stronger fluorescence emission, which may be assigned to the lower HOMO–LUMO+1 energy gap (4.08 eV). With strong fluorescent emissions, polymer 10 may be a good candidate for potential applications of fluorescent material. Although having the lowest HOMO–LUMO+1 energy gap (4.00 eV), 11 exhibits a very weak emission band under the same experimental conditions. This can be probably attributed to the competitive quenching effect of the iodide anions according to an internal heavy atom mechanism caused by the introduction of the metal ions and halide anions, and the disorder of iodide ions of 11 in crystallography has also the negative effect on its fluorescence intensity.

elements.content: In summary, by the reactions of an asymmetric multidentate ligand pmtc– and Cd­(II) salts with different counteranions Ac–, X– (Cl–, Br–, I–), NO3 –, NO2 –, SO4 2–, SCN–, and N3 –, 12 novel Cd­(II) coordination polymers were successfully obtained. Due to the different shapes, sizes, and coordination abilities of the counteranions, the polymers have different structures, in which the counteranions show structure-directing behavior, resulting in different and interesting topology structures. Furthermore, 2 and 4 have the same (42·6·103)­(42·63·8)2(42·6) topology that is a new framework topology and has not been reported before. The photoluminescence of 9–11, as probed by FMO calculations, arises from n → π* transition. The photoluminescent properties show that the coordination anions make great contribution to fluorescent emission of the Cd­(II) coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, by the reactions of an asymmetric multidentate ligand pmtc- and Cd(II) salts with different counteranions Ac-, X- (Cl-, Br-, I-), NO3 -, NO2 -, SO4 2-, SCN-, and N3 -, 12 novel Cd(II) coordination polymers were successfully obtained. Due to the different shapes, sizes, and coordination abilities of the counteranions, the polymers have different structures, in which the counteranions show structure-directing behavior, resulting in different and interesting topology structures. Furthermore, 2 and 4 have the same (42⋅6⋅103)(42⋅63⋅8)2(42⋅6) topology that is a new framework topology and has not been reported before. The photoluminescence of 9-11, as probed by FMO calculations, arises from n → π* transition. The photoluminescent properties show that the coordination anions make great contribution to fluorescent emission of the Cd(II) coordination polymers.

The lithium 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole- 3-carboxylate ligand was synthesized according to the procedure described in .

Synthesis of 1-(4-Pyridinylmethyl)-1<italic>H</italic>-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic Methyl Ester

1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic methyl ester (4.30 g, 0.034 mol), 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride (5 g, 0.04 mol), and K2CO3 (10.12 g, 0.073 mol) were dissolved in 80 mL of acetonitrile solution. The mixture was stirred and heated to reflux for 24 h. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the brick-red solid was chromatographed on silica gel with CH3CH2OH/CH2Cl2 (1:28); the white solid was obtained (4.85 g, 0.022 mol) in 65% yield.

Synthesis of Lithium 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1<italic>H</italic>-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylate

The ester prepared above (5.41g, 0.023 mol) was dissolved in 50 mL of CH3OH and THF (1:1) mixed solution, and then LiOH (1.11 g, 0.026 mol) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After filtration, pmtcLi (4.62 g, 0.022 mol) was obtained in 91.4% yield. Mp: 192–196 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ: 8.410 (s, 1H), 8.370 (dd, 2H), 7.140 (d, 2H), 5.440 (s, 2H) (Figure S1). IR spectra (KBr, cm–1): 3072m, 2973m, 1631s, 1510m, 1432m, 1625m, 1370w, 1287s, 1212w, 1045m, 806m, 678m, 479m.

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(pmtc)<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Polymer 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (9.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (1:1, 4 mL) heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless single crystals of 1 were collected (yield:75% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C36H32Cd3N18O16 (%): C, 32.98; H, 2.44; N, 19.24. Found: C, 32.92; H, 2.46; N, 19.25. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3430m, 3098m, 1657s, 1615s, 1482s, 1423s, 1368s, 1281m, 1189m, 1069m, 1031s, 833m, 666m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(pmtc)<sub>2</sub>(μ<sub>2</sub>-SO<sub>4</sub>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CdSO4·3/8H2O (7.7 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (2:3, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 100 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained (yield: 55% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C18H12Cd2N8O9S (%): C, 29.14; H, 1.62; N, 15.11. Found: C, 29.05.; H, 1.92; N, 15.02. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3670m, 3398s, 3117s, 1667s, 1616s, 1516m, 1473s, 1426s, 1358m, 1320s, 1291s, 1117s, 1082s, 1025s, 842m, 665m, 591m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of [Cd­(pmtc)­(SCN)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

PmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol), and NH4SCN (3.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) were dispersed in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (1:4, 5 mL) and then sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, which was heated at 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Bright yellow of 3 was collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C10H7CdN5O2S (%): C, 32.11; H, 1.87; N, 18.73. Found: C, 32.09; H, 1.80; N, 18.85. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3129m, 2108s, 1611s, 1513m, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1295s, 1229m, 1187m, 1028m, 825s, 799m, 771m, 666w, 587w, 473m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(pmtc)<sub>2</sub>(SCN)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and NH4SCN (3.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (4:1, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Bright yellow of 4 was collected (yield: 75% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C20H14Cd2N10O4S2 (%): C, 32.11; H, 1.87; N, 18.73. Found: C, 32.27; H, 1.99; N, 18.78. Anal. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3425m, 3129s, 2108s, 1745m, 1615s, 1513m, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1296s, 1229m, 1187s, 1069m, 1028s, 825s, 771m, 799m, 666m, 473m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(pmtc)<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

PmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol), and NaN3 (3.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (1:4, 5 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 60 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless of 5 was collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C36H32Cd3N22O10 (%): C, 34.01; H, 2.52; N, 24.25. Found: C, 33.99; H, 2.50; N, 24.30. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3416s, 3091m, 2039s, 1656s, 1607s, 1478m, 1422m, 1360m, 1352m, 1297m, 1284s,1225m, 1199m, 1034s, 836m, 817m, 719w, 667m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd­(pmtc)<sub>2</sub>]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

Polymer 6 was synthesized in a similar way to that described for 2 except using Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) instead of CdSO4·3/8H2O (7.7 mg, 0.03 mmol). Colorless block crystals were isolated and washed by water. Yield: 70% based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C18H14CdN8O4 (%): C, 41.64; H, 2.70; N, 21.59. Found: C, 41.86; H, 3.08; N, 21.16. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3462s, 3092m, 2937w, 1649s, 1474s, 1422s, 1355m, 1286s, 1035s, 826m, 668m, 593m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of [Cd­(pmtc)­(NO<sub>2</sub>)­(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>7</bold>)

Polymer 7 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and NaNO2 (3.5 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:3, 6 mL) at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature, bright yellow of 7 were collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C10H11CdN5O5 (%): C, 30.48; H, 2.79; N, 17.78. Found: C, 30.59; H, 2.86; N, 17.67. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3128m, 2107m, 1611s, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1236s, 1270s, 1027m, 825m, 666w, 587w (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(pmtc)<sub>3</sub>(NO<sub>2</sub>)]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>8</bold>)

Polymer 8 was synthesized by a solvothermal procedure similar to that described for 7 except using solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:2, 5 mL) instead of solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:3, 6 mL). Bright yellow of 8 was collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C27H21Cd2N13O8 (%): C, 36.80; H, 2.39; N, 20.67. Found: C, 37.19; H, 2.70; N, 20.25. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3128m, 2107m, 1611s, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1236s, 1270m, 1027m, 825m, 666w, 587w (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(pmtc)­(Cl)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>9</bold>)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CdCl2 (5.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (4:1, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature, colorless of 9 was collected (yield: 70% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C18H18Cd2Cl2N8O6 (%): C, 29.26; H, 2.44; N, 15.17. Found: C, 29.10; H, 2.55; N, 15.08. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3442s, 2989w, 1617s, 1565m, 1474s, 1473s, 1421m, 1364m, 1293s, 1182m, 1034m, 840w, 813m, 665m, 498m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd­(pmtc)­(Br)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·CH<sub>3</sub>OH}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>10</bold>)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd­(Ac)2·2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and KBr (6.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:2, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless of 10 was collected (yield: 70% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C19H22Br2Cd2N8O7 (%): C, 26.54; H, 2.56; N, 13.04. Found: C, 26.63; H, 2.72; N, 12.99. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3416s, 3094m, 2985m 1616s, 1482s, 1421s, 1361m, 1306m, 1290s, 1227m, 1183m, 1070m, 1033s, 846m, 809m, 712m,667m, 469m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {Cd­(pmtc)­(I)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>11</bold>) and {Cd­(pmtc)­(I)]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>12</bold>)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CdI2 (11.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:1, 4 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless of 11 and 12 were collected (yield: 53% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C9H9ICdN4O3 (%) (11): C, 23.45; H, 1.95; N, 12.16. Found: C, 23.72; H, 2.26; N, 11.96. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3423s, 3093w, 1615m, 1593s, 1485s, 1419m, 1296s, 1191m, 1031w, 1018m, 847s, 816w, 712w, 665w, 498w (Figure S2). Calcd for C9H7ICdN4O2 (%) (12): C, 24.41; H, 1.58; N, 12.66. Found: C, 24.50; H, 1.59; N, 12.69. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm–1): 3425s, 3092w, 1610m, 1583s, 1480m, 1409m, 1286m, 1183m, 1031m, 1015s, 847m, 816m, 710w, 663m, 495m (Figure S2).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Ligand

The lithium 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole- 3-carboxylate ligand was synthesized according to the procedure described in .

Synthesis of 1-(4-Pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic Methyl Ester

1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylic methyl ester (4.30 g, 0.034 mol), 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride (5 g, 0.04 mol), and K2CO3 (10.12 g, 0.073 mol) were dissolved in 80 mL of acetonitrile solution. The mixture was stirred and heated to reflux for 24 h. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the brick-red solid was chromatographed on silica gel with CH3CH2OH/CH2Cl2 (1:28); the white solid was obtained (4.85 g, 0.022 mol) in 65% yield.

Synthesis of Lithium 1-(4-pyridinylmethyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazole-3-carboxylate

The ester prepared above (5.41g, 0.023 mol) was dissolved in 50 mL of CH3OH and THF (1:1) mixed solution, and then LiOH (1.11 g, 0.026 mol) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After filtration, pmtcLi (4.62 g, 0.022 mol) was obtained in 91.4% yield. Mp: 192-196 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O) δ: 8.410 (s, 1H), 8.370 (dd, 2H), 7.140 (d, 2H), 5.440 (s, 2H) (Figure S1). IR spectra (KBr, cm-1): 3072m, 2973m, 1631s, 1510m, 1432m, 1625m, 1370w, 1287s, 1212w, 1045m, 806m, 678m, 479m.

Synthesis of {[Cd1.5(pmtc)2(NO3)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

Polymer 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (9.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (1:1, 4 mL) heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless single crystals of 1 were collected (yield:75% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C36H32Cd3N18O16 (%): C, 32.98; H, 2.44; N, 19.24. Found: C, 32.92; H, 2.46; N, 19.25. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3430m, 3098m, 1657s, 1615s, 1482s, 1423s, 1368s, 1281m, 1189m, 1069m, 1031s, 833m, 666m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd2(pmtc)2(μ2-SO4)(H2O)]} n  (2)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CdSO4⋅3/8H2O (7.7 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (2:3, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 100 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained (yield: 55% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C18H12Cd2N8O9S (%): C, 29.14; H, 1.62; N, 15.11. Found: C, 29.05.; H, 1.92; N, 15.02. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3670m, 3398s, 3117s, 1667s, 1616s, 1516m, 1473s, 1426s, 1358m, 1320s, 1291s, 1117s, 1082s, 1025s, 842m, 665m, 591m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of [Cd(pmtc)(SCN)] n  (3)

PmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol), and NH4SCN (3.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) were dispersed in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (1:4, 5 mL) and then sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, which was heated at 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Bright yellow of 3 was collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C10H7CdN5O2S (%): C, 32.11; H, 1.87; N, 18.73. Found: C, 32.09; H, 1.80; N, 18.85. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3129m, 2108s, 1611s, 1513m, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1295s, 1229m, 1187m, 1028m, 825s, 799m, 771m, 666w, 587w, 473m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of [Cd2(pmtc)2(SCN)2] n  (4)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and NH4SCN (3.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (4:1, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Bright yellow of 4 was collected (yield: 75% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C20H14Cd2N10O4S2 (%): C, 32.11; H, 1.87; N, 18.73. Found: C, 32.27; H, 1.99; N, 18.78. Anal. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3425m, 3129s, 2108s, 1745m, 1615s, 1513m, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1296s, 1229m, 1187s, 1069m, 1028s, 825s, 771m, 799m, 666m, 473m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd1.5(pmtc)2(N3)]⋅H2O} n  (5)

PmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol), Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol), and NaN3 (3.3 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (1:4, 5 mL) were placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 60 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless of 5 was collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C36H32Cd3N22O10 (%): C, 34.01; H, 2.52; N, 24.25. Found: C, 33.99; H, 2.50; N, 24.30. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3416s, 3091m, 2039s, 1656s, 1607s, 1478m, 1422m, 1360m, 1352m, 1297m, 1284s,1225m, 1199m, 1034s, 836m, 817m, 719w, 667m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd(pmtc)2]} n  (6)

Polymer 6 was synthesized in a similar way to that described for 2 except using Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) instead of CdSO4⋅3/8H2O (7.7 mg, 0.03 mmol). Colorless block crystals were isolated and washed by water. Yield: 70% based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C18H14CdN8O4 (%): C, 41.64; H, 2.70; N, 21.59. Found: C, 41.86; H, 3.08; N, 21.16. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3462s, 3092m, 2937w, 1649s, 1474s, 1422s, 1355m, 1286s, 1035s, 826m, 668m, 593m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of [Cd(pmtc)(NO2)(CH3OH)] n  (7)

Polymer 7 was synthesized hydrothermally in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and NaNO2 (3.5 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:3, 6 mL) at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature, bright yellow of 7 were collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C10H11CdN5O5 (%): C, 30.48; H, 2.79; N, 17.78. Found: C, 30.59; H, 2.86; N, 17.67. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3128m, 2107m, 1611s, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1236s, 1270s, 1027m, 825m, 666w, 587w (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd2(pmtc)3(NO2)]} n  (8)

Polymer 8 was synthesized by a solvothermal procedure similar to that described for 7 except using solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:2, 5 mL) instead of solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:3, 6 mL). Bright yellow of 8 was collected (yield: 80% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C27H21Cd2N13O8 (%): C, 36.80; H, 2.39; N, 20.67. Found: C, 37.19; H, 2.70; N, 20.25. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3128m, 2107m, 1611s, 1478s, 1425s, 1369m, 1236s, 1270m, 1027m, 825m, 666w, 587w (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd2(pmtc)(Cl)2(H2O)2]} n  (9)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and CdCl2 (5.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (4:1, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature, colorless of 9 was collected (yield: 70% based on cadmium). Anal. Calcd for C18H18Cd2Cl2N8O6 (%): C, 29.26; H, 2.44; N, 15.17. Found: C, 29.10; H, 2.55; N, 15.08. IR spectra (KBr/pellet, cm-1): 3442s, 2989w, 1617s, 1565m, 1474s, 1473s, 1421m, 1364m, 1293s, 1182m, 1034m, 840w, 813m, 665m, 498m (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[Cd(pmtc)(Br)(H2O)]⋅CH3OH} n  (10)

A mixture of pmtcLi (6.3 mg, 0.03 mmol) and Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (8.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) and KBr (6.0 mg, 0.05 mmol) in solvent of H2O/CH3OH (3:2, 5 mL) was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature; colorless of 10 was collected (yield: 70% based on cadmium). cln_elements.content: In order to investigate the thermal stabilities of 1–6, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been performed, as shown in Figure S3. The complexes were heated in a temperature range of 30–800 °C in air atmosphere. It can be found that the TG curves of 1, 2, 5, and 6 show three-step weight loss, while 3 and 4 exhibit two-step weight loss. For 1, 2 and 5, 6, the first step of decomposition can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules, coordinated water molecules, or solvent molecules. The second and third sharp weight loss is corresponding to the collapse of the framework. The TG curves of 3 and 4 reveal that the frameworks of 3 and 4 are thermally stable up to 310 °C. Complex 3 begins to decompose at 310 °C and ends at about 683 °C. 4 undergoes sharp destruction ranging from 310 to 660 °C. In the end, all the complexes form CdO as the product at 672 °C for 1, 708 °C for 2, 683 °C for 3, 660 °C for 4, 610 °C for 5, and 644 °C for 6. Table S2 reports the calculated and experimental weight losses, and the temperature range of decomposition for 1–6.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

In order to investigate the thermal stabilities of 1-6, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been performed, as shown in Figure S3. The complexes were heated in a temperature range of 30-800 °C in air atmosphere. It can be found that the TG curves of 1, 2, 5, and 6 show three-step weight loss, while 3 and 4 exhibit two-step weight loss. For 1, 2 and 5, 6, the first step of decomposition can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules, coordinated water molecules, or solvent molecules. The second and third sharp weight loss is corresponding to the collapse of the framework. The TG curves of 3 and 4 reveal that the frameworks of 3 and 4 are thermally stable up to 310 °C. Complex 3 begins to decompose at 310 °C and ends at about 683 °C. 4 undergoes sharp destruction ranging from 310 to 660 °C. In the end, all the complexes form CdO as the product at 672 °C for 1, 708 °C for 2, 683 °C for 3, 660 °C for 4, 610 °C for 5, and 644 °C for 6. Table S2 reports the calculated and experimental weight losses, and the temperature range of decomposition for 1-6.
